One thing is that if the main or only reason for buying a stock is because the price looks low, I can tell you that there is always a lower price possible. Other thing though is that sometimes when everyone really hates a stock so much you cant find a buyer and it drops every day, but that same company actually has ok fundamentals or has some redeeming features, that period when its being thrown away can a good time to buy. When meta was said to be going out of business, teens were going to quit it, advertisers fleeing, completion taking everything, whistleblowers reminding us that Zuck and the execs are soulless ghouls, congress going to split it up... well, the balance sheet was actually amazing and the economy was warming up under a new administration. Those two little points of light were why I thought 90 might be a buying opportunity. When Netflix has run out of popular shows and they were getting more cancels per day than signups and management was falsely blaming Russia for their woes, the stock was straight down from 701 to 160 with no buyers in sight. Next stop 99 they said. But there were glimmers. It was the number one streaming service that everybody had. Its the one that seems to work best. And they said anyone who tries to cancel will be offered an adtier option to leave. We know both of those are up like 47x from their obituary moments. Maybe this is the time for Celsius. Or maybe when its 5.

Minor disclaimer I work for a company that makes beverages that contain green tea extract. We have had a ton of meetings concerning what constitutes a safe level of green tea extract consumption. The general consensus is that Celsius is on the high side due to the target audience, consumption patterns, and serving size. The Celsius demographic skews female and 1845, which is absolutely fine. If you have a healthy liver, typical consumption should never be an issue. I repeat never be an issue. But, if you are obese, have a sedentary lifestyle, or have existing liver impairment genetic, alcoholism, etc, then you might want to go easy on it. Where it becomes an issue is twofold its smaller serving size lends itself to multiple servings per day, and due to its enhancing cognitive function of caffeine, people are drinking it solo between meals, so its absorption rate is not ideal for processing in your liver. Once again, in moderation it should be fine. But since its in a small can, you are more likely to get 23 shots a day, and not exercisingmetabolizing it completely since it isnt being paired with food.
Thanks for a more international look

I work for a company that makes beverages containing green tea extract Which company and what product? small can, you are more likely to get 23 shots a day The challenge for Celsius is expanding distribution, not getting fat guys to drink 3 or more a day. Distribution is everything in beverages. When you buy a soda at the movies or drive through lane or grocery store or vending machine or cstore, you get whats on the shelf. Their challenge is being on the shelf. In the unlikely event that someone makes the leap from this terrible article that people are saying to something actually real, the fix is as easy as tinkering down the green tea level a bit, which would save money and probably wouldnt change the taste.

Companies usually dont go public for the heck of it. Usually its because 1. Company needs money to do stuff like pay down debt, expand the business 2. IPOs arent always caused by majority shareholders wanting liquidity. Sometimes PE firms and other investors who own meaningful stakes want an exit and the majority shareholders consent to letting the company go public. Many times shareholders want to keep the company private when going public only serves to reduce control and bring more public scrutiny. It also makes them vulnerable to things like takeover bids.

replies.text: Probably not Probably A lot of people have claimed that TDFs are too conservative for a young investor. I disagree, though it does depend on the fund the investor. Bonds account for very little of the difference in performance between an allUSstock portfolio many TDFs designed for young investors. Bonds have had little impact on the performance of these performance TDFs its mostly been the international stocks. Adding international stocks doesnt make a fund more conservative. Historically, US stocks international stocks have taken turns outperforming each other. US stocks have dominated recently, but that tide could turn at any time. Im most familiar with Vanguards TDFs, so Ill use them as an example. Ive never invested in one, but theyre a great choice for a lot of investors who value convenience are willing to pay a little bit for it. Vanguard TDFs start out with a 9010 stockbond allocation stick with that for many years before starting to gradually shift more towards bonds twentyfive years before the target date. The difference in performance between a 9010 portfolio a 1000 portfolio is usually pretty small, but the difference in risk is usually much larger. This makes it much easier for an investor to hold onto the TDF through a bear market instead of selling in a panic, a move that would cost much more than the performance difference. For a USonly portfolio, over the last 30 years, the performance difference has been less than 0.4 CAGR. However, the risk standard deviation difference has been about 1.5. I expect longer time periods would show similar results. 22 years into this comparison, the 9010 portfolio was slightly ahead. Only the longest bull market in US history created much of a gap. Why then, you may ask, have funds like Vanguard Total Stock Market Fund VTSAX VTI beaten Vanguards TDFs by such a large margin recently? The answer is not bonds its international stocks. So, pick an allUSstock portfolio total market or SP 500 over a TDF if you like. But please understand that the TDF is only slightly more conservative has its own advantages. Of course, past performance is not an indicator of future results. I didnt include international bonds in my analysis because their impact on the portfolio is small. Also, the comparison period would have been much shorter because some years of data are not available for international bonds.

For starters, dont sell yourself short with the negative self talk about being behind. Thats not productive. A personal brokerage is not a good place for an emergency fund. The last thing you want in an emergency is a devalued account AND a taxable event on top of it, because it was in an investment account. This goes in a High Yield Savings Account HYSA or Certificate of Deposit CD. Youre doing a good job with savings based on what youre putting away now. You have to decide your own risk tolerance and invest accordingly. I dont see anything wrong with a target date fund other than minor nitpicks. There are more aggressive target date funds though, so check there before selecting stocksETFs.

Time builds wealth, not always strategy. I would continue doing what youre doing because your investment horizon has another 2530 years. If you change anything at all it would be to try to save more if possible.
Acorns sucks nuts. High fees just to schedule your weekly contribution for you. Just schedule a recurring 20 weekly contribution to your brokerage and save on fees. Hell, go nuts and make it 50.

Target Date Funds are great. Set it and forget it. They are a bit on the conservative side but are safe. If you want to be more aggressive you could do VOO, SPLG, VTI and add some VXUS. Just my opinion.
